Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: A conversion candidate's final, decisive study session before their Beit Din appearance is scheduled.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, my heart pounding. The hospital’s address blinked on my delivery app, a red warning flashing: “Critical—medical supplies, urgent.” I knew what was in the back of my van—specialized medication, needed for a patient’s treatment. I was already running behind, traffic thicker than usual. My phone buzzed again. This time, it was a message from Miriam, the conversion candidate. “Rabbi, I’m so nervous. Will you be there for our final session before the Beit Din?” I could picture her anxious face, the months of study and hope riding on this last meeting. I was supposed to be at the synagogue in twenty minutes, to guide her through the final questions, to reassure her, to fulfill my promise as her rabbi. But the hospital was in the opposite direction, and the clock was ticking for both deliveries—one of medicine, one of faith. My hands tightened on the steering wheel, torn between the urgent needs of my two worlds, each demanding my presence, each expecting me not to fail.
